div.p: 1. III:45. Tuesday. Neponset Bridge Proprietors annual Meeting Squantum—

Harvey Field brought me a printed Petition to the Legislature of the Commonwealth for the abolition of Capital punishment— He asked if I would sign it— I declined, and told him I had not brought my mind to the conclusion that it would be for the good of the community— We have by the Laws of the Commonwealth only five crimes punishable with death—Treason, Murder, Burglary, Arson, and Rape— Now a Law to save the precious lives of men guilty of either of those crimes has in my judgment little claim to the merit of humanity. They are a class of People with whom humanity cannot sympathise— A law to prohibit the killing of Rattlesnakes would be as rational, and might be urged also upon principles of humanity— There is another point of view in which the abolition of capital punishment at this time is specially objectionable. While such exceeding tenderness is felt for the lives of Traitors, Murderers and Robbers, here is the Sovereign people, hanging up without judge or jury, gamblers, and even the mere circulators of printed papers recommending the abolition of Slavery. On one hand we have the most reckless disregard of human life, and the punishment of death summarily inflicted for offences comparatively light and even for that which is no offence at all, on the other Traitors and Murderers, are taken into peculiar favour—and their lives must be preserved and guarded, as if they were the very jewels of the Land. The signs of the times are portentous— All the tendencies of Legislation, are to the removal of restrictions from the vicious and the guilty, and to the exercise of all the powers of Government, Legislative judicial and executive, by lawless assemblages of individuals— I have however no
doubt that the punishment of death will be abolished in this Commonwealth—and in all probability throughout this union— I had a morning visit from Dr Thomas Gray of Jamaica-Plains, with Mr Joseph Russell—and Mr Samuel M’Farland brought me a Letter of Introduction from Mr Thomas M. T. M’Kennan of Washington County, Pennsylvania, a member of the last, re-elected to the present Congress— Mr M’Farland is a wool-grower, travelling in this party of the Country, for pleasure and curiosity— There was a Lady with him, who said her residence was in this State.— Barnard Sargent brought me a Letter from his father to the Commissioner of the general Land-Office, which I promised to forward— Charles went to Boston, and returned at One O‘Clock, and then went with me to the annual party of the Proprietors of Neponset Bridge at Squantum— The Proprietors Meeting was first held; at which I presided. The Clerk, (Thomas Greenleaf) The Treasurer and Superintendent of the Bridge (G. W. Beale) and seven Directors (Quincy, Head, Wayles, Miller, Foster, Beale, and T. Greenleaf) were unanimously re-elected— The vote of full-power to the Directors to act for the Proprietors as they might for themselves was adopted, and a vote that the Directors of the Farm School on Thompson’s Island should pass the Bridge Toll-free, on their visits to that Establishment, till further order of the Proprietors.— The meeting was over in a quarter of an hour and was followed by a similar meeting of the Directors— I administered the Official Oath to Thomas Greenleaf as Clerk and to George W. Beale, as Treasurer and Superintendent— We had a dinner of Chowder, fried fish, Madeira and Champagne wine, Melons, Apples, Pears Peaches and Plums— The party consisted of Josiah Bass, G. W. Beale, Thomas Greenleaf, and his Son E. Price, Daniel Greenleaf, Edward Miller, President Josiah Quincy, and his Son—the Coll. Mr Wayles and his Son, Mr Whitney and Mr Lunt, with my Son Charles and myself. The weather was not foul but chilly, and Mr Wayles inclined to change the day of the annual meeting to a warmer Season. We came home before Sunset, and met Mary and Charles’s wife walking. Elizabeth C. Adams had dined at our house but was gone home. I received this day a Letter from Dr Waterhouse—
2. IV:10. Wednesday.—

At five this morning, according to previous agreement, I roused from bed Mr. E. Price Greenleaf, and we walked together round Neponset Square, excepting that instead of going over Gulliver’s brook we turned in at the Railway passage and went through that to the cross road from Blacksmith’s Corner to the Neponset Bridge road— The sky was lowering, and there was a light sprinkling of rain, before we went out and another while we were walking, but we got home quite dry, after a walk of two hours— Immediately afterwards the rain came on in a succession of showers all the morning, and until within an hour of Sunset— I confined myself to my chamber, and to the writing of my journal old and new— When it cleared off the pressure upon my breast and Spirits was so heavy that I took another solitary walk, nearly to the Quincy gate and found myself relieved. In the Evening I read several of the Letters from Horace Walpole, to Sir Horace Mann, which are very amusing, and as descriptive of the downfall of his father’s Administration, full of interest— The Legislature of the Commonwealth, met this day for an adjourned Session to decide upon a revised Code of the whole Statute Law of the State.—
3. . . .:15. Thursday.

E. Price Greenleaf came and knocked at my door, at half past four O’Clock this morning— We walked together to Germantown, and back and reached my gate about half-past seven— The morning was clear, but the ground so wet, particularly the grass of the cross roads was somewhat uncomfortable and made my feet sore— Charles and his wife, with their children Louisa and John, and Mary with her daughter Fanny went to Boston, and
and returned to dine. My garden, nursery and Seminary visit was very short There is at this Season little vegetation of any interest to observe— Almost all the seedling trees having attained their summer’s growth now remain stationary, till the fall of the leaf, and thence till the next Spring— A stake of the European vine at the Southwest corner of the House, cut away in July, supposed to be dead, and which I stuck out in the Summer-House Cellar, has put forth a vigorous shoot— I was so much wearied with my morning walk, that I could not accomplish my daily task of writing.— Mr Beale, and his daughter Anne were here this Evening.
4. V. Friday.

The weariness and fatigue of yesterday gave me a longer Nights repose than usual, and the Clock had struck five this morning before I rose. Mr Prïce Greenleaf immediately afterwards knocked at my door, and we walked round by the Braintree Meeting house, and returned over the magnificent summit of Penn’s hill— My feet were galled yesterday so that the walking of this day was painful— It was near 8. O’Clock when I got home— The worst effect of this morning walk is that it shortens much my daily writing—and this I cannot prevent— My garden visits are now almost entirely confined to planting seeds and Stones of Apples, Pears, Plums, Cherries, Apricots and Peaches for the vegetation of next Spring— I am still so careless in marking the precise seed which I sow, that I fear I shall not know which of them it is that come up. Mrs. Philadelphia Cook, an old woman from Mendon came in towards Evening, and was here upwards of an hour, insisting upon my reading certain manuscripts of her composition upon the subject of Temperance— She claims to be the first person who founded a Temperance Society—of which there were only twelve members all women and one half of them members of her own family— They pledged themselves to total abstinence from the use of wine and spirituous liquors, except in cases of pain and distress—an exception sufficiently wide— Mrs Cook however urgently preaches total abstinence, and protests against the use of spirituous liquors even as medicine— She gave a very self Satisfied account of her immense labours and sacrifices and sufferings in the cause of Temperance— She enquired if I had received about eight years ago when President of the United States two anonymous Letters upon Temperance— I said I had no recollection of them, but I had received many anonymous Letters, of which I took little or no account. She said she had written those Letters and would be glad if I could now find them— But I told her my files of Letters received at that time were at Washington— She said she wanted them because she had now determined to have her manuscripts printed— I read two or three of those she had with her, which were merely declamatory, and confused in Style— A sort of Chaos from which might be worked out one of Lucius Manlius Sargent’s Dissertations— I read till dark, when she went away, to lodge at French’s Tavern; leaving with me the longest of her manuscripts to read, and saying that she would come again and take it to-morrow Morning— She is a widow 65 years of age has two Sons and two Daughters all but one married, and her face and form look well-suited to perform the part of one of the Weird Sisters of Shakespear— After she was gone I walked with Charles to Mrs T. B. Adams’s, where Mary, and Charles’s wife had gone to take tea— Mr Beale and his daughter Ann were there—Mr Miller and his family afterwards came in, with Elizabeth—Mrs Angier who is convalescent from her fever was also there—and Mr Price
Greenleaf, to whom I mentioned that I must ask him to suspend our morning walks for a few days, my feet being so much galled that I walk with pain— We rode home.
5 IV:15 Saturday

There is a publication by professor Olmsted and a Mr Loomis of Yale College, New-Haven, announcing that they have observed the great Comet of Halley which has been expected for some Months— They say it is in the Constellation of Taurus, North of the two horns of the Bull, at right angle with those two Stars, and about as distant from the eastern-most of them, as they are from each other— Precisely in that spot I saw this morning after I rose, with the naked eye, a luminous spot rather nebulous, but whether the comet or a star of the fifth magnitude at the foot of the twin Castor I could not without a Telescope ascertain— Mrs Philadelphia Cook came again to converse with me upon the subject of Temperance— I read while she was here the manuscript she had left with me. It was a narrative of what one poor obscure woman (herself) had atchieved in the great cause of Temperance, from the first female association of twelve persons which she formed at Mendon to the present time— She had directed the Stageman to call for her here; but he sent a boy with a chaise for her— She was exceedingly earnest for total abstinence, not only from ardent Spirits but from wine—cyder—even small beer— All fermented liquors without exception— She had enquired into my own habits, and I had told her, I usually drank one glass of wine, at or after dinner, and often two— Just before she went away she asked to say a word to me specially and said she had examined my countenance, which did not look well; and she asked me to abstain from drinking wine altogether, for one month, by way of trial— I thanked her for her advice and said I would think of it— She said wine was poison—it was fire—it was alcohol— I asked her if wine was poison, or fire, how it happened that the first miracle performed by Jesus Christ was that of turning water into wine, by Gallons, at a wedding feast— She said there was no evidence that he drank any of it himself—and that he made good pure wine—but all the wine now made was adulterated—made in copper vessels— To drink it was to pour poison down the throat. She asked me what I thought about her having her manuscripts printed— I said she should consult with Printers for that; and I wished her all possible success in her labours for the promotion of Temperance— Charles went into Boston, and returned to dine— He brought me from Degrand a certificate of 3 Shares of Stock in the Atlas Insurance Company: and Apricot and Bolmer Plum Stones, from Edward Cruft— In the garden I filled a Pot with 1. Greengage Plum stone 5 cherry stones, 4 Williams Apple seeds and 2 Sugar Pear cores, and 10 seeds of the same— I planted also Row 6 in the cleared Hazel bush patch with 12 whole Sugar Pears; and covered the remainder of the 5th. row with Cherry stones and North Nursery Crab-seeds— This Evening Barnard Sargent, brought his deed of land in Ohio, with the spelling of his name rectified. I promised to forward it for him, and advised him to call here again about the last of this month.

6. IV. Sunday— Heard Mr George Whitney, in the morning from Job 7:16. “I would not live always”—and in the afternoon from Mark 14.8. “She hath done what she could.” As Mr George Whitney advances in years, his confidence in himself increases. He writes in a style more ambitious than correct— He reads well, and has a very animated delivery, and with a conscious self-satisfaction, with which his hearers are apt not to sympathise— His discourse this morning was a disquisition upon the unreasonableness and folly of wishing to live always—a disease not very common among men—we cling to life for the present moment, and are never ready to die now—but we all know we must die sooner or later, and naturally long only for an undefined continuation of existence— Against this love of life, there is perhaps not
much necessity for spiritual exhortation—when Job speaks the words of the text, he is in a paroxysm of despair, and it immediately succeeds a declaration that his life is loathsome to him— A very impressive exhortation against the wish to live always is a superfluous waste of the Preacher’s powers— The afternoon Sermon was more practical— Mr Whitney descanted upon the exquisite perfection of the person to whom such a testimony was borne— The lesson to be learnt of doing what we can, is an obvious inference from this text; and the Sermon closed with a reference to the story of the widow’s mite cast into the Treasury, and to the memorable commendation of her gift, by Christ— Mr Whitney freely uses figurative language, but not always with congruity— As a sample of his style, when he was describing the miseries of human life, as arguments to quench the desire to live always, he spoke of a man, borne down by the heavy hand of weakness— His manner of preaching is not so acceptable to the People as that of Mr Lunt.— I read the 9th. Sermon of the 7th. Volume of Saurin, upon the bad use of Riches— He says there are cases of Conscience hard to solve— That honest hearts may sometimes not exactly know what Religion requires and exemplifies by putting the question of resistance against Tyrants. No preacher in this Country, at the present age, would consider this as a question hard to solve. The doctrine of the Sermon is that in the use of riches, a man is mad, who loses sight for one moment of the shortness of human life, and of the chance that his own life may be taken from him this very night.— Again says the Preacher— [“]The thought of approaching death leads to the thought of approaching judgment— Now upon what will that approaching judgment turn? Think you it will be upon certain vain speculations? upon certain barren virtues which are the whole moral system of some of us? Think you that God will ask you, have you well taken care to make yourself inaccessible to your fellow citizens? have you well closed your door against those importunates who came to speak to you of their interests? Have you well assumed an outward appearance suited to freeze those who might wish to approach you? Have you well taken care to escape from the eyes of the world into caverns and desarts?— Ah! my brethren what ideas are these of the moral system of Jesus Christ? Ah! my brethren, where have you been brought up? A man who continually thinks that he may die in a few days—that he may die this very night; such a man even thereby thinks that he may be judged in a few days—or even this very night, and even thereby never loses sight of the community, to the good of which his duties as a Christian engage him to labour.” This is a sample of Saurin, in his best manner— I walked this Evening with E. Price Greenleaf to Coll. Josiah Quincy’s— Charles and his wife also came, and spent the Evening there— Miss Sophia Quincy was there.

7. IV. Monday. Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine I had an uninterrupted day; and hoped to have had industry to make progress with my work— But I was much disappointed— My visit to my garden, nursery and seminary was too long though the only fruit I brought from them except twelve dwarf tree Apples which I gathered for the seed was a variety of enormous caterpillars—among the rest a nest upon my old shell-bark tree—black caterpillars two inches long; large in proportion, and voracious enough to strip half the tree of its foliage. I make it a point now to plant a row of seeds and stones every day. I always want a large portion of seedlings of the current year, and they absorb almost all my attention—few of those of the second year exhibit perceptible growth, and after that, I scarcely notice them enough to save them from perishing. There was an evening party at Mrs T. B. Adams’s, to which Charles and his wife, and I went—Mr and Mrs Edward Miller with their daughter, Coll. and Mrs Quincy, and Miss Sophia constituted with us the company—with Louisa C. Smith—Elizabeth C Adams, and Georgiana Harrod— Mrs Adams received while the company were there information of
of the death of Mr Phineas Foster, the husband of her Sister, and the Guardian of her two Sons yet in their minority— He died at 8 O’Clock this morning of consumption. This incident though not known to me or to most of the company cast a gloom over the social circle— Mrs Angier who is yet there is quite convalescent— Mrs Daniel Greenleaf, and E. Price and Mary Ann of the other family were likewise there. I agreed with Price to walk with him again at five O’Clock to-morrow Morning— Our Legislature are in Session, revising the code of Statute Law; but there is little notice taken of their proceedings— The attempted assassination of Louis Philippe, King of the French, on the 28th. of July last, is the most remarkable event to furnish conversation of the present times— A second infernal machine, from which his escape, though not wholly unhurt, was almost marvelous— We rode home soon after nine
8. IV. Tuesday

At ten minutes past five this morning E. Price Greenleaf knocked at my door and we took a walk of 6 miles over the canal landing Bridge round to the Weymouth Turnpike and back by the Episcopal Church—out two hours— Lewis Bass the Selectman sent me a note to enquire if I could go and view the ground which they wish me to give the town, to widen the road on Penn’s Hill. I sent him word I would meet him there to-morrow Morning at Sunrise— I made two visits to my Garden and Nursery—one from Noon till dinnertime, when I planted in row 7. of the cleared Hazel-bush patch 14. Cores of the Orange pear now ripe—my object now being to identify the particular sort of seed sown, to compare with the growth and progress of the plant when it comes up— This is specially desirable for the Apple and Pear— First to observe the relative rapidity and slowness of their growth, the difference between which is enormous; and secondly to observe which seeds produce the healthy plants, to discern them from those, which take the blight almost immediately after they come up— I have many seedling plants of the present year of both kinds, but not knowing from what particular seed either of them came, I have no useful guide for the selection of seed in future— I have therefore now, planted in each of the rows of the cleared hazle-bush patch, one kind of Pears or cores only and have successively taken the Jenneton, Jargonel, Catherine, Sugar and Orange Pears, one to each row, as they successively ripened— I propose to do the same with the Apples—in the rows and in the Pots— I have nearly ascertained that my Apple-seedlings of most rapid growth are from the Office or woodhouse tree, and those of slowest growth from the Dwarf tree.— The last are indeed so very slow; that I cannot expect to live to see any of them come to a bearing age— Still my experiments afford me so pleasing a pastime that I repeat them from year to year, hoping that the results may prove hereafter useful to my descendants or to others, when I myself may be forgotten— With the same purpose, I took out my grand daughter Mary-Louisa this afternoon into the garden, where she planted—South and East of the Nursery gate 1. Bolmer Plumstone—one Cruft Apricot-Stone. 1 whole Squantum Peach. 2. Peach-stones 6. whole Orange Pears, 20 North-Nursery Crab Apple seeds and 1. whole apple. 3 wild cherries and 3 Greenleaf cherries all in one row— Some of them I hope may come up, and then that she will remember that they were trees planted from the seed with her own hand. I would willingly give this taste to every individual of my posterity, believing that if I could it would be profitable to after ages—a simple taste, a cheap pleasure—a source of improvement in the cultivation of the earth; a link of attachment to the soil tending to strengthen the love of their Country, and to preserve them from the vices of dissipation and folly— I filled also Pot 13. and planted in it 1. Bolmer Plum. 1 Cruft Apricot stones, Orange Pear-seeds, Office Apple seeds, wild and Greenleaf Cherries. I answered a Letter from Dutee J. Pearce.
9. IV:15. Wednesday.

Price Greenleaf came about ten minutes before five this morning and we walked over Penn’s Hill. We were at the Corner of my lot on the side of the hill, as I had sent word to Mr Lewis Bass, that I would be, just before Sunrise, but he was not there— We continued our walk; passed by the 12th. Milestone, and came by the cross road into the Braintree and Weymouth Turnpike and thence home—a little short of 7 Miles—out two hours— Charles went to Boston and returned to dine. In my Garden visit, I planted 8 whole North Nursery Crab Apples and 7 whole Catherine Pears in row, under North garden fence, next to the gate of the Nursery— After dinner I rode with Mary, Charles and his wife, and his son John Quincy to Milton, and called at Mrs R. B. Forbes’s—but she was gone upon a Journey and her daughters were walking out—we returned home.— My old journal of 1834 flags inexcusable— I answered a Letter from Revd. Dr Charles Lowell, of the Committee of the Massachusetts historical Society, declining to deliver one of the course of Lectures which the propose to have there this autumn— Charles brought me an invitation to go with him next Week to Plymouth Mr P. C. Brooks proposes to be of the party, and to extend the excursion to the island of Nantucket—a captivating proposal—
10 IV:15. Thursday.

I called this morning on E. Price Greenleaf, and we walked to the Railway house and thence along the way and over the fields till we came out into the cross road, that issues west of the 9th. Milestone— We saw under the sheds five of the Pillars destined for the Court-house at Boston— One of them is fluted; I measured one of them which I found 25 feet long—with four feet six inches diameter at the base, and three feet four inches at the top. I wrote a very short Letter declining the invitation from the Committee of the Citizens of Concord to attend the celebration of their second centennial anniversary, which is to be the day after to-morrow. The Committee say that their town was the first Settlement in the interior of New-England, and so says the wonder-working Providence— This was the birth-day of Mary, and of her daughter Georgiana-Frances, who was born here at Quincy, and is this day five years old. This afternoon she planted between two willow stakes on the patch opposite my old walnut tree a short row of 1. Bolmer plum-stone, 1. Cruft Apricot Stone 2 Peach-Stones, Office Apple-seeds, Greenleaf and wild Cherries— I myself in row 7. upon the cleared hazel bush patch in the garden planted peach and plum stones, Wild and Greenleaf Cherries, and North Nursery crab-apple seeds—and 1. Bolmer Plum-stone, and 1. Cruft Apricot Stone at the Seminary Corner next the gate. I gathered this day some Ash keys, and some wild cherries, fallen from the tree, for seed— Mr Lunt and E. Price Greenleaf spent the Evening with us.
11. IV:15. Friday.

E Price Greenleaf came at 5. and we walked on the road to Neponset Bridge, and round the short square of the way to Squantum— Charles went to Boston, and returned to dine. After dinner Price Greenleaf came and inspected the cherry and apple-seedlings, almost all of which he found had taken. Mary-Louisa planted a Green gage Plum stone and Fanny a Peach-stone in their two several rows— Dr Wainwright of Boston, and Mr Philip Hone of New-York with his Son, paid me an afternoon visit— I answered a Letter from Dr Waterhouse at Cambridge, but retrieved less than half a page of my last years Journal— As the days shorten I find it impossible to take my morning walk and to perform the task I had imposed upon myself of copying two pages of my last volume every day— Still less can I keep along the current of my correspondence or in truth pursue any subject of literary interest— I fall asleep even in attempting to read the Letters from Horace Walpole to Sir Horace Mann.
12. IV:15 Saturday— Boston and back to Quincy.

At five I called upon E. Price Greenleaf, who from the lowering appearance of the sky had concluded that I should not incline to walk, and had returned to bed. He immediately rose and we walked round the Square turning in beyond the 9th. Milestone, and returning by the way of the Meeting House— After breakfast I went into Boston with my Son Charles and we returned home to dine— I met at the Corner of Summer Street Mr Isaac P. Davis, with whom I agreed upon the arrangements for our excursion to Plymouth and Nantucket— Mr Brooks and he will take the stage on Monday Morning at half-past six, and stop to take in Charles and me at my house about half past seven— Mr Davis’s plan is for a tour of eight days. I called at A. H. Everett’s, but he was not at home— Then at James H. Foster’s.— He returned last Evening from a journey to the town of Gorham in Maine, where he has a brother residing, and where he took and left two of his daughters, Louisa and Mary, who is feared to be in a decline— I visited for the second time this Season the Athenaeum gallery, where there are very good marble busts of the late Chief-Justice Marshall and of Thomas Handasyd Perkins—and a few additional Portraits, to those which were there at my former visit in June— The Portraits are all indifferent.— I called upon Mr Edward Cruft—and visited his garden, where his grapes look promising—the rest of his fruit not remarkable— Left a card at Mr. B. F. Hallett’s, in Williams Street, he not being at home— After purchasing a great Coat ready made at Kelleys shop in Congress Street, I found at the United States Branch Bank Mr John Parker, its President—politically desponding.— He said he was seventy nine years of age, and that it might outlast him, but would not outlast me—he meant the Union— Yet he acknowledged that the Country was enjoying a state of unexampled prosperity.— At one O’Clock I went to Charles’s Office, and we came home. After dinner I planted the Peach and Plum Stones that I had brought from Boston, in two rows in the Garden—one on each side of the Nursery gate—together with Apple seeds, Catherine and Orange Pears and wild Cherries— In the Evening I answered a Letter from David P. Page, of Newbury-Port, received this morning— An invitation to deliver the introductory Lecture to the Lyceum in that town—on the 9th. of October next— I declined.
13. IV:15 Sunday

Heard Mr Nathaniel Hall, the newly settled Colleague of my Classmate Dr. Thaddeus M. Harris at Dorchester— The morning Sermon was from Luke 17.17 “And Jesus, answering, said, Were there not ten cleansed? but where are the nine?” It was a discourse upon ingratitude— Mr Hall commented with some severity upon the ten Lepers cleansed, mentioning the loathsomeness of the disease—the seclusion from all society to which those infected with it were condemned, the greatness of the blessing conferred upon the men thus instantaneously healed, and the baseness of ingratitude in the nine who never returned to glorify God or to bless their deliverer.— One only in ten thought of grateful return for the miracle upon his person—and that one a Samaritan—or as Jesus called him a stranger— Mr Hall dined with us. His afternoon Sermon was from Luke 2.49—“wist ye not that I must be about my fathers business?” parts of both these discourses were pathetic— Mr Hall is a young man of much promise, and has an original turn both of composition and of delivery. He is a Cousin of Charles’s wife. She and Mary
and their three daughters attended the afternoon meeting— I read the tenth Sermon of the 7th volume of Saurin, upon the long suffering of God towards the Amorites—because the iniquity of the Amorites was not yet full The preacher tells his hearers that the case of the Amorites was their own—that God spares them only because their iniquity is not yet full; and that his terrible judgments are in reserve for them— This is a severe denunciation, but when he comes to specify, he disclaims all application to individuals and speaks only of national sins— These consist in tolerating licentious books; in sacrificing the reformed religion to Policy—in harbouring hatred and discord—in complaining of persecution and practising it, and in captious criticism upon preachers and their discourses. He stops himself in the midst of this enumeration of deadly sins; says it is long enough—and that the wretched age for which he had been reserved seemed to have taken for its model that which drew down the vengeance of God upon Sodom and Gomorrah; Admah and Zeboim.— Did the preacher believe this?
26. V. Saturday

My hand is so thoroughly crippled that I found it almost impossible even to frank the answers to Letters which Mary wrote for me.— These were answers to a Letter of invitation from George Grennell junr. and five others, a Committee of the Inhabitants of Deerfield, to attend the celebration next Wednesday of the anniversary of Lathrops Battle with the Indians under king Philip in 1675, commonly called the Bloody Brook Massacre, and to lay the corner Stone of a monument to be erected in commemoration of the Event— An Oration is to be delivered by Edward Everett. Deerfield is 120 miles from my home, a greater distance than I feel myself justified in going to attend a mere ceremonial celebration or to hear an Oration even from Edward Everett— I declined— The other Letter was to Samuel Hazard of Philadelphia, in answer to one from him making enquiries respecting the Instructions to the Marshals for taking the census of 1820.— On rising this morning, I found it too cold for sitting in my chamber, and resumed my morning walk— I went to the rise of Penn’s Hill; and there met Henry Hardwick, and told him that I had viewed the spot of ground on the mount Wollaston beach, which he has been urging me to sell him— That he should have it for fifty dollars— He thought this an exorbitant price, and I trust will give me no more trouble about it— Returning home I met Captain Underwood who said he wanted the lease of the lot upon which he has built an house, upon the land given by my father to the town of Quincy— This lease has been in the hands of Coll. Josiah Quincy junr. for a petty alteration since the meeting of the Supervisors of the Adams Temple and School fund, on the 11th. of July last— I told Captain Underwood, I would see to it— I planted a row of Pears with five Greenleaf Peach Stones, four Peach Plum Stones from Plymouth, Cherry Stones wild cherries and Apple seeds in the patch South and East of the Nursery gate— The dwarf Apple trees fruit was gathered ripe— I read a large part of a very dull Dissertation upon a Congress of Nations, marked E—and in the Evening several Letters from Horace Walpole to Sir Horace Mann—
27. IV:15. Sunday

Rising thus early I could occupy the time only in walking, which I did on the Neponset Bridge-road, and round by that leading to Squantum— At meeting I heard in the morning Mr Lunt, from Luke 7.18–50. he read it for the Chapter, without repeating it as the text of his discourse— It contains the account of the message sent from John the Baptist to Jesus to enquire—art thou he that should come—or look we for another and also the incident of the dinner at the house of Simon the Pharisee, when the woman who was a sinner washed the feet of Jesus with ointment, and the remarks of Jesus to the Pharisee on that occasion— The exposition upon this Story was admirable— Mr Lunt gave notice that the communion would be administered next Sunday— He read also a Letter from a Committee of the town of Charlestown, soliciting contributions for the sufferers by the recent great fire at that place, and gave notice that a collection for their benefit would be taken next Sunday afternoon— After dinner the Services were performed by Judge Cranchs SonPearce Cranch, who has just completed his course of studies at the theological Institution at Cambridge— He had not preached more than two or three times before, one of which was last Sunday afternoon here. His performance was very creditable for a beginner— Mr Degrand came out, dined and spent the day with us, and Coll. Josiah Quincy junr was here this Evening. Elizabeth C Adams also dined with us— I read Saurin’s Sermons 11 and 12 of Volume 7. upon Regeneration.
28. IV:30. Monday— Hingham Bicentennial celebration

E. Price Greenleaf called this morning and we walked round the small square of the old Mill bridge, and back, by the Stone-meeting— I went to Hingham alone, and attended the anniversary celebration of the second century completed since the Settlement of that town— I went first to the Union Hotel, where I found the President of the day, Mr Ebenezer Gay, the Orator Mr Solomon Lincoln, and the Committee of arrangements— The acting Governor Armstrong, with General A. H. S. Dearborn Adjutant General of the Commonwealth and Coll. Robert C. Winthrop, the Governor’s aid, and Mr William B. Calhoun a member elect of the House of Representatives of the United States in the 24th. Congress soon came in from Boston, and Peleg Sprague, late a member of the Senate of the United States from Maine Judge John Davis came in the Steam-boat— Mr Heman Lincoln, and Mr John A. Shaw a Senator of the Commonwealth from the County of Plymouth were also there— At noon the procession went from the Union Hotel escorted by two military companies in uniform to the meeting house of the first congregational Church, a building 153 years old— An Oration was delivered by Solomon Lincoln; preceded and followed by Prayers from the Ministers of the several Churches of the town, Joseph Richardson, Hale, Charles Brooks and A. A Folsom, interspersed with Anthems and Hymns written for the occasion— The procession was then resumed and proceeded to the Old Colony House; where under an adjoining pavilion a dinner for about 300 persons was prepared— At this dinner toasts were given to the acting Governor Armstrong, to Mr Sprague and to me, in answer to which each of us made a short Speech— We then left the table, and I went with the Governor and Mr Sprague to Willard Hall, where we had been invited to the collation of the Ladies—of these there were between two and three hundred— Thence about Sunset I took my departure and returned home—
